abstract_summ: If we start with two stars that are too close in mass to each other, then the mass transfer takes place after the secondary star has developed a helium core and it ends forming a PN and a WD.In the WD-NS reverse evolution the primary star evolves and transfers mass to the secondary star, forms a PN, and leaves a WD remnant.Using post-processing Monte Carlo radiative transfer calculations of ionizing radiation, we compute f_esc from cluster stars and non-cluster stars formed during a starburst over ~100 Myr in each galaxy.We find that the averaged f_esc over the lifetime of a star particle follows a similar distribution for cluster stars and non-cluster stars.We find that cluster stars on average have comparable f_esc to non-cluster stars.
title_summ: Two Wolf-Rayet stars at the heart of colliding-wind binary ApepEccentric grazing envelope evolution towards type IIb supernova progenitorsDetectability of kilonovae in optical surveys: $post$-$mortem$ examination of the LVC O3 run follow-upOn rare core collapse supernovae inside planetary nebulaeDetecting ultra-high energy cosmic ray anisotropies through cross-correlationsA Survey for C II Emission-Line Stars in the Large Magellanic CloudThe contribution of globular clusters to cosmic reionizationThe Role of Outflows, Radiation Pressure, and Magnetic Fields in Massive Star FormationThe 100 pc White Dwarf Sample in the SDSS FootprintWinds in Star Clusters Drive Kolmogorov Turbulence
title_abstract_phrases: Winds in Star Clusters Drive Kolmogorov TurbulenceIntermediate and massive stars drive fast and powerful isotropic winds that interact with the winds of nearby stars in star clusters and the surrounding interstellar medium (ISM).If we start with two stars that are too close in mass to each other, then the mass transfer takes place after the secondary star has developed a helium core and it ends forming a PN and a WD.In the WD-NS reverse evolution the primary star evolves and transfers mass to the secondary star, forms a PN, and leaves a WD remnant.Using post-processing Monte Carlo radiative transfer calculations of ionizing radiation, we compute f_esc from cluster stars and non-cluster stars formed during a starburst over ~100 Myr in each galaxy.We find that the averaged f_esc over the lifetime of a star particle follows a similar distribution for cluster stars and non-cluster stars.
